title: Mum was in coma for three days after drinking just one sip of Diet Coke
text:
Elizabeth Perkins, 30, says her family’s life has been ‘made hell because of the sugar tax’ (Picture: Caters)

A mum-of-two suffered a severe allergic reaction and fell into a coma for three days after taking a sip of Diet Coke.

Elizabeth Perkins, 30, and her two sons are severely allergic to artificial sweeteners aspartame and asphetame, which are found in thousands of products, and are used in high quantities in diet soft drinks.

Elizabeth says she had gone into her local pub and asked for a ‘full-flat coke’ when a staff member gave her a diet coke instead.

Speaking for the first time after the incident nearly killed her, Elizabeth, from Swadlincote, Derbyshire, said: ‘I don’t think people realise what a big difference something like that makes, and since the sugar tax, fewer and fewer places are serving the full fat drinks.

‘Some people automatically give you the low-sugar or sugar free versions but for me, that mistake could be fatal.

‘I’d asked for a full fat coke, and stressed that it had to be full fat as usual to the bartender.

‘But once I took my first sip and straight away, I knew it tasted strange, and I could feel the usual sickness start, like I was going to be sick.’

Elizabeth says the incident ‘nearly killed her’ (Picture: Caters News)

Elizabeth says she felt dizzy and the room ‘went dark’ as her body tried to fight off the reaction.

She was rushed to hospital, where she spent three days in a coma.

Not only does Elizabeth have to avoid the artificial sweeteners herself, the condition is genetic, so her two sons, Matthew, six and two-year-old Jacob, are also at risk every time they reach for a sweet treat.

Their lunchboxes are entirely homemade, as Elizabeth has discovered ‘almost everything contains the deadly ingredients’.

She had gone to her local pub and asked for a ‘full-flat coke’ when she was given the diet version instead (Picture: Caters News)

Elizabeth’s two sons also have to be very careful about what they eat (Picture: Caters News)

She also says the sugar tax has made the family’s life hell, as pubs and shops can’t afford to have the ‘sugared versions of food and drink.’

The impact has been so severe that the mum and her two sons avoid social outings.

Elizabeth says she has found it heartbreaking to watch her sons miss out on birthday cakes because the icing contains artificial sugars.

She added: ‘It feels like we’re penalised, for needing the sugared versions of things when really, it’s a necessity – we need it to survive.’
